Posts.Title: There is light at the end of the tunnel!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I haven't been here for a while. Some of you may remember me. First of all I would like to thank all the incredible ladies here who's words of wisdom and kind caring messages got me through some very dark days. London lass, optimistic, snowys mum, seaspirit, joedec toxophilite to name a few. Apologies if I have missed anyone my memory isn't what it was. I often think of you all . My story to anyone struggling right now you need to here this. I was diagnosed October 2015. Double mastectomy 6 months chemo hospitalised after all bar one. Tissue expander and finally diep flap Feb 2017. My life has basically been on hold for the last 3 years. Friends have nearly all disappeared.  Apparently I should be over it. I lost my job soon after diagnosis. I've been to hell and back with treatment and various ops. I've suffered severe depression and my physcologist tells me I had a breakdown. All my relationships have suffered especialy with my partner of nearly ten years. He got depressed too. and lost his job so he struggled to cope. For nearly a year I sat on a beanbag in my living room with my curtains closed. I wasn't eating or sleeping and I was smoking terrible I know. I was told by an acquaintance how lucky I was that my partner didn't leave after my double mastectomy as her husband was a boob man. I was mocked for being overweight. 12 steroids a day every month for nearly a year can do that to a person. To them I was fat and lazy. I was constantly asked why arnt you back at work from people who have never worked might i add. Things were so bad i barely left the house in 2 years. My partner could not cope with me. He got more and more depressed and we were at breaking point. Then something happened I finally rang mcmillian again for a few days and they persuaded me to see my doctor. . She arranged for me to have more counselling weekly and antedepressents.  I was totally against these for a long time but as I couldn't string a sentence together without breaking down I had to take them. Within a couple of months I started to feel better and was finely able to deal with the aftermath of the whole cancer experience. I also did a kind of group therapy which was amazing.  Half way through the 8 weeks course I was offered a job by someone I briefly new. She is a home carer it's her company and they look after my father in law. It is not a career I have ever considered but I am a different person now because of this job. It is incredibly hard mentally as I do care so very much but it is so rewarding. Im still having some counselling every other week but I am now able to deal with everything that has happened to me. To all of you wonderful people know this when you are down there is only one way to go. Never ever give up because although your lives will never be the same , there is a new life out there for you . You will be braver and stronger than ever and live the life you deserve. I got through this and so can you. It's taken me nearly three years to get where I am today but I did it!!!!! Love to you all. Xxxxx

Posts.Title: 2 years after diagnosis so down

Posts.Content: Hi to everyone im just wondering if anyone else feels like i do. Double mastectomy 2015 6 months chemo now tamoxifen. Couldnt do immediate reconstruction as i was a smoker. Ive had tissue expander op in august in preparation for diep flap in january. I honestly think i feel worse now than when i was diagnosed i just cant understand it. My friends have gradualy dwindled away as they seem to think im fine. I had to let some go as i got so angry when they told me they had a cold or a hangover or something else trivial. There were the ones who told me how lucky i was that my partner didnt leave me after mastectomy. Then the others who repeatedly told boob jokes. How can people be so cruel. Family have been no help really either. I have only recently joined this site and wondering if theres anyone else feeling the way i do. So sorry to moan i know i should consider myself lucky to have got through the ops and treatment im just struggling to move on. Financialy its been tough to i had no insurance and my partner is self employed and dosent always get paid on time. Some days i dont even open my curtains i never used to be this way. I just hope i feel better after my op my partner has been supportive but i worry about him to hes doing his best to support me and my 14 year old daughter but he is so stressed with work. I have only recetly joined this site so apologies if i do anything wrong.

Posts.Content: Hi lesley thankyou so much for you're reply. My beast friend of 44 years told me last year she woulsnt bother me again. Do you think maybe hes struggling to help because of his wife maybe. Bless you i am so sorry you lost you're parents. You must have neen a great boss how lovely of her. I said the same to myself a cancer diagnosis and still smoked until a year after chemo. I finaly did it 17th feb this year one of the hardest things i have ever done. I actualy smoked more after diagnosis. Definitely not ridiculous i understand and would like to help you with that. A dear friend helped me sadly she is no longer here but she was an inspiration. Its an addiction its not as easy as saying im not going to smoke . Even a cancer diagnosis dosent stop the craving. Its about learning to cope without them. You cant just stop its been a part of you're life for such a long time. Ask me anything and i will help if i can. My surgeon wouldnt operate unless i stopped and i couldnt imagine looking like this forever so i had to. I know i should see my gp i ring mcmillian sometimes it helps. Thankyou again you have been a great help to me. You look after yourself too. Xxx
